snippet.textDisplay: I really can't stand the "bread and butter" wow quests. I can't believe the notion that most people like it either. It's completely unengaging even by their own definition and it was the reason I quit in BfA. I was dying of boredom and couldn't be bothered to cap even 1 character in a brand new expansion. They should just have an engaging narrative/struggle in each zone that you work towards fixing which grants all your experience (with some side quest stuff for those interested). Kinda like the Witcher or something. They technically already have that but quests like "Collect 10 monkey butts" are not QUESTS they are CHORES and don't serve the story.
snippet.textOriginal: I really can't stand the "bread and butter" wow quests. I can't believe the notion that most people like it either. It's completely unengaging even by their own definition and it was the reason I quit in BfA. I was dying of boredom and couldn't be bothered to cap even 1 character in a brand new expansion. They should just have an engaging narrative/struggle in each zone that you work towards fixing which grants all your experience (with some side quest stuff for those interested). Kinda like the Witcher or something. They technically already have that but quests like "Collect 10 monkey butts" are not QUESTS they are CHORES and don't serve the story.

snippet.textDisplay: I think most people will love this and i think it open doors. Midnight will infurate the high-end raiders since they now can complain about class changes and addons. See ragequitting and drama, that we have seen many times before. But think abou this; the changes made will not make a casual a great raider. It will not make a casual top DPS in pvp and pve. There are still complexitiy, and there is still playstyle etc. BUT! If the gap between casuals and pro's with 50 keybinds and mousebuttons are made a bit smaller, and makes casuals master the class better, than its a win-win. So as for now, i am glad that the big channels do NOT cater into that nagging about slashing, gutting and face-rolling. The focus should be on what this video is about, about the wide array of content.
snippet.textOriginal: I think most people will love this and i think it open doors. Midnight will infurate the high-end raiders since they now can complain about class changes and addons. snippet.textDisplay: I still watch your videos but I'll be honest modern wow just doesn't respect my time, nor reflect the game I'd like to play anymore. I tired to like it after legion and I just cant anymore. The top of the ladder is just too inaccessible now, and being a middle of the row maybe clearing heroic raid is just not satisfying. You'll never see your true bis in any meaningful amount of time, the mechanical ceiling is in the stratosphere. The story lacks any real testosterone, which is ironic if your appealing factors are rogues, warlocks and warriors. The final nail in the coffin is Blizzard, the ban free Hong Kong, steal your tourney funds Blizzard. Cant be bothered anymore, all good will is gone, though I'm always glad to see you're out there grinding content and making videos. Hair looks great btw!
snippet.textOriginal: I still watch your videos but I'll be honest modern wow just doesn't respect my time, nor reflect the game I'd like to play anymore. I tired to like it after legion and I just cant anymore. The top of the ladder is just too inaccessible now, and being a middle of the row maybe clearing heroic raid is just not satisfying. You'll never see your true bis in any meaningful amount of time, the mechanical ceiling is in the stratosphere. The story lacks any real testosterone, which is ironic if your appealing factors are rogues, warlocks and warriors. snippet.textDisplay:
Why do TBC zones still look so stunning compared to everything that came after?
Even today, areas like Nagrand, the Black Temple entrance, and Magisterâ€™s Terrace have a visual and atmospheric depth that newer expansions rarely match. Magisterâ€™s entrance in particular captures the essence of the entire TBC expansionâ€”elegant, eerie, and timeless. It still gives me chills every time I see it.
The world felt bigger back then. Outside of Quelâ€™danas, zones werenâ€™t cluttered with mobs every few steps. You could explore without constantly being forced into combat just for walking down a road. That spatial breathing room made the world feel vast and immersive.
After all these years, I still think TBC had the best-designed zones. And while todayâ€™s gear models are technically more advanced, most post-Legion sets lack the iconic identity TBC gear had. Even the Legion T6 redesign looks absolutely gorgeousâ€”but that just proves how well-crafted the original TBC gear was.
snippet.textOriginal:
Why do TBC zones still look so stunning compared to everything that came after?
Even today, areas like Nagrand, the Black Temple entrance, and Magisterâ€™s Terrace have a visual and atmospheric depth that newer expansions rarely match. Magisterâ€™s entrance in particular captures the essence of the entire TBC expansionâ€”elegant, eerie, and timeless. It still gives me chills every time I see it.
The world felt bigger back then. Outside of Quelâ€™danas, zones werenâ€™t cluttered with mobs every few steps. You could explore without constantly being forced into combat just for walking down a road. That spatial breathing room made the world feel vast and immersive.
After all these years, I still think TBC had the best-designed zones. And while todayâ€™s gear models are technically more advanced, most post-Legion sets lack the iconic identity TBC gear had. Even the Legion T6 redesign looks absolutely gorgeousâ€”but that just proves how well-crafted the original TBC gear was.
